content: How can I help you today?
I've been really distracted and struggling to focus lately, and my wife suggested I talk to someone. Things have been rough at home, and I guess I’m just feeling stuck.

Thank you for sharing that—sounds like things have been challenging for you lately, and you’re carrying a lot right now. It’s good that you’re here. What’s been on your mind the most about feeling stuck?

It’s mainly my family. My son is having a lot of behavioral issues, and my wife and I have no idea how to help him. It’s taken a toll on us, and it feels like our marriage is falling apart. It’s overwhelming.

That sounds incredibly heavy, trying to navigate your son’s challenges while also feeling the strain on your marriage. It seems like you care deeply about your family and want to find a way to make things better, even when it feels overwhelming. How have you been coping with everything that's going on?

Honestly, I don’t feel like I’m coping at all. I’ve been shutting down, avoiding things, and I can’t seem to unwind or focus on anything, even work. It’s just been hard to know what to do or where to even start.

It sounds like you're feeling weighed down, and shutting down has been your way of handling everything that feels so out of control right now. With everything pulling at you—your son, your marriage, work—it must be tough to even figure out which direction to turn. What helps you the most, even in little ways, when things feel like this?
Honestly, nothing really helps right now. Even the things I used to enjoy don’t feel the same anymore. It’s hard to find the energy or focus to even try.

It sounds like you’re feeling disconnected from the things that used to bring you some relief or joy, and even trying feels like a heavy lift in this moment. It’s clear that the weight of everything is making it hard to move forward. What kind of support, if any, do you wish you had right now?
I don’t even know anymore. Maybe someone who could just tell me what to do or give me answers. But at the same time, I’m not sure if anything would really help. It all just feels really uncertain.

That uncertainty can feel paralyzing, like you’re looking for answers but not sure if they even exist right now. It seems like you just want things to feel manageable again, but figuring out where to begin feels too overwhelming. What would it mean for you to feel a little less stuck in all of this?

I guess it would mean finding a way to help my son and somehow getting on the same page with my wife. If we could work together again, maybe things wouldn’t feel so hopeless. But I just don’t know how to get there.

It seems like what’s most important to you is finding some stability for your son and reconnecting with your wife, so you can face this together as a team. Even though you’re feeling uncertain, just acknowledging this shows how much you care about your family. What feels like the first step for you in moving toward that place?

I honestly don’t know what the first step would even be. Maybe talking more with my wife about everything, but we’ve just been so distant lately, and it’s hard to even start those conversations without things getting tense. It feels like such a big mountain to climb.

It sounds like opening up with your wife feels like it might help, but the distance and tension make it feel so hard to approach. The mountain seems huge right now, and even thinking about the first step feels overwhelming. What would it look like to approach that conversation in a way that feels a little more comfortable or less tense?

Maybe if I could just listen more instead of trying to fix everything right away. I think she feels like I’m not really hearing her, and I guess I haven’t been. But it’s hard when I’m feeling so overwhelmed myself.

That insight is really meaningful—it sounds like you’re recognizing that being present and listening could help her feel more heard, even if it’s not easy with everything you’re holding. It shows how much you value your relationship. What would help you feel more grounded or steady, so you could create that space to really hear her?

Maybe just taking a moment to breathe and remind myself why I’m doing this—to help my family and get us back on track. I think I just need to try to let go of the idea that I have to have all the answers right now and focus on just connecting with her in the moment.

Taking that moment to breathe and reconnect with the “why” behind all of this could be such a powerful grounding step. Letting go of having all the answers and simply focusing on connection shows a lot of strength and care for your family. Is there anything else on your mind you'd like to talk through before thinking about how to move forward?
I think I'm okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
